contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "mouth" emphasizes that Yahweh has spoken and what he says will certainly happen. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has spoken" or "Yahweh has said that this will happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the mouth of Yahweh has spoken it

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are synecdoches for weapons of any kind. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: swords ... spears ... sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words are synecdoches for tools of any kind that people use in peaceful activity. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: plowshares ... pruning hooks

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hands" is a synecdoche for the people themselves. Alternate translation: "their own craftsmanship" or "their own work" or "things they have made with their hands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: craftsmanship of their own hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "fingers" is a synecdoche for the people themselves. Alternate translation: "things that they have made with their own fingers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: things that their own fingers have made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "the eyes" stands for God himself, who is glorious. Alternate translation: "him who is glorious" or "Yahweh who is glorious" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the eyes of his glory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "branch" is a synecdoche that represents the crops Yahweh will cause to grow in the land of Israel. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will cause the crops in Israel to be beautiful" or 2) "branch" is a metaphor that refers to the Messiah. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the branch of Yahweh will be beautiful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the metonym "hands" represents the person who has done something. Alternate translation: "what Yahweh has done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the doings of his hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "I have seen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my eyes have seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "voice" represents the Lord himself. Alternate translation: "the Lord say" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the voice of the Lord say

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks as if the kings were the armies they led. Alternate translation: "Rezin ... and Pekah ... led their armies up" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Rezin ... and Pekah ... went up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Rezin" represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: "Therefore, Yahweh will bring Rezin and his army against the people of Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Therefore Yahweh will raise up against him Rezin, his adversary

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "mouth" refers to the person. Alternate translation: "every person speaks foolish things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: every mouth speaks foolish things

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "him" here also refers to the king of Assyria. But it does not mean God is only sending the king; he is sending with him the army of Assyria. Alternate translation: "I send the army of Assyria ... I order them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I send him ... I order him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "I" refers to the king of Assyria. He was the leader of the Assyrian army and took credit for what the army did at his command. Alternate translation: "I and my army have brought" or "we have brought (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I have brought

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "He" refers to "the Assyrian" which represents the king of Assyria and his army. Alternate translation: "He and his army will strike" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He will strike

contextId.occurrenceNote: The earth is pictured as if it has four corners, and those corners are its most distant places. This refers to everywhere on earth where those people might be. Alternate translation: "from even the most distant places of the earth" or "from all over the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: from the four corners of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the Assyrian king and his army. Alternate translation: "the king of Assyria and his army" or "the Assyrian army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the Assyrian

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is represented by his "heart" which emphasizes his emotions. God speaks of his great sadness as if his heart cried out. Alternate translation: "I am extremely sad about what is happening to Moab" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche or figs-metaphor]] and
contextId.glQuote: My heart cries out for Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "my heart" represents Yahweh and his sad feelings. He compares his sigh to the sound of a sad song played on a harp. Alternate translation: "So I sigh like a sad song on a harp" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: So my heart sighs like a harp for Moab

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ephraim was the largest tribe in Israel. Here it represents the entire northern kingdom of Israel. Alternate translation: "Strong cities will disappear from Israel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Fortified cities will disappear from Ephraim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "men" represents people in general. Alternate translation: "people will look" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: men will look

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents the people who look. Alternate translation: "they will look" or "the people will look" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: their eyes will look

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their "hands" to emphasize that they made the altars or idols. Alternate translation: "that they made with their hands" or "which they themselves built" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the work of their hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "nations" refers to the armies of those nations. Alternate translation: "the rushing of the enemy armies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the rushing of nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bread" represents food in general. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: with bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "ears" represents Isaiah as a whole. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Yahweh of hosts revealed this to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: This was revealed in my ears by Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "feet" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "who went to distant places to live and make money" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: whose feet carried her far away to foreign places to settle

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "pit" and "snare" represent all the different bad things that will happen to people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the pit, and the snare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "snare" represents all the different bad things that will happen to people. People will run away to escape one bad thing but they will just experience another bad thing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: caught in the snare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "spirit" represents the speaker as a whole. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my spirit within me seeks you earnestly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "one" refers to a mighty king who also represents his powerful army. Alternate translation: "the Lord sends a king with his powerful army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the Lord sends one who is mighty and strong

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "lips" and "tongue" represent the foreigners who speak a different language than the Israelites do. It is implied that this refers to the Assyrian army that will attack Israel. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will speak to this people through enemy soldiers who will speak a foreign language" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: with mocking lips and a foreign tongue he will speak to this people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) these are a synecdoche representing anything in general that will cause destruction or 2) these are a metaphor referring to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Hail ... the floodwaters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "flood" is a synecdoche that represents anything in general that will cause destruction or 2) "flood" is a metaphor referring to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When the raging flood passes through

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "those who are blind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the eyes of the blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "you yourselves will see your teacher" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: you will see your teacher with your own eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "ears" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "You will hear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Your ears will hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bread" represents food in general. Alternate translation: "he will cause the ground to produce plenty of food for you to eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: bread with abundance from the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "lips" and "tongue" are metonyms that represent Yahweh speaking. And, Yahweh speaks with so much anger and power that it is spoken of as if his tongue were a fire. Alternate translation: "When he speaks his fury is like a fire that destroys everything" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: His lips are full of fury, and his tongue is like a devouring fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are referred to by their "hands" the emphasize that they made something with their hands. Alternate translation: "that you have sinned by making with you own hands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: that your own hands have sinfully made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the foolish person is referred to by his heart to emphasize his inner thoughts. Alternate translation: "he plans evil things in his heart" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: his heart plans evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the whole day, not just the morning. Alternate translation: "every day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: every morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Bashan and Carmel are represented by their trees. Alternate translation: "there are no more leaves on the trees in Bashan and Carmel" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Bashan and Carmel shake off their leaves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers the audience by their "eyes." Alternate translation: "You will see ... you will see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Your eyes will see ... they will see

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the audience by their "hearts." "The terror" refers to their war with the Assyrians. This can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "You will remember the terror that the Assyrians caused you when they attacked" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Your heart will recall the terror

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people are referred to by their "eyes" to emphasize what they are seeing. Alternate translation: "you will see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: your eyes will see

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is referred to by his "mouth" to emphasize what he has said. Alternate translation: "for Yahweh has commanded it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: for his mouth has commanded it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the plants in the desert blossoming as if the desert itself were blossoming. Alternate translation: "its plants will blossom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: blossom

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "weak hands" and "knees that shake" represent a person who is fearful. Alternate translation: "Strengthen those whose hands are weak and whose knees shake from fear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Strengthen the weak hands, and steady the knees that shake.

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are referred to by their hearts, which emphasize their inner feelings. Alternate translation: "to those who are fearful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: those with a fearful heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to people who cannot speak. They are referred to by their "tongues" to emphasize their healing. Alternate translation: "mute people will sing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the mute tongue will sing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This uses a person's head to mean the person as a whole. Alternate translation: "they will have everlasting joy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: everlasting joy will be on their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib represents himself and his army. Alternate translation: "Sennacherib and his army ... attacked all the fortified cities" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Sennacherib ... attacked all the fortified cities

contextId.occurrenceNote: These men destroyed the cities listed by conquering them with their armies. Here the word "fathers" refers to his father and his other ancestors who were kings. Alternate translation: "that my fathers destroyed with their armies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: that my fathers destroyed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the messengers are referred to by their "hand" to emphasize that they personally gave it to the king. Alternate translation: "that the messengers gave him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: from hand of the messengers

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that humans made these idols with their own hands and are therefore worthless. Alternate translation: "because they were false gods that men made out of wood and stone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: for they were not gods but the work of men's hands, just wood and stone

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib speaks of himself conquering many things. He is actually conquering them with the armies and chariots that he commands. Alternate translation: "We have gone ... We will cut ... we will enter" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I have gone ... I will cut ... I will enter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib speaks of himself conquering many things. He is actually conquering them with the armies and chariots that he commands. Alternate translation: "We have dug ... we dried ... our feet" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I have dug ... I dried ... my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. Alternate translation: "His army will not come ... They will not come" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: He will not come ... He will not come

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Assyrian king refers to both him and his army. Alternate translation: "they came ... they will not enter" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: he came ... he will not enter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Sennacherib refers to both him and his army. They all left Israel and returned home to Assryia. Sennacherib returned to the city Nineveh. Alternate translation: "Sennacherib and his army left Israel and went home, and Sennacherib stayed in Nineveh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Sennacherib king of Assyria left Israel and went home and stayed in Nineveh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Hezekiah refers to himself my his "eyes" to emphasize that he is looking for something. Alternate translation: "I" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "from Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: from Yahweh's hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "voice" represents the person who cries out. Alternate translation: "Someone cries out" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: A voice cries out

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "mouth" represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "for Yahweh has spoken it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hand" represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has done this" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the hand of Yahweh has done this

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "their eyes" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "for they are blind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: for their eyes are blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their "hearts." Alternate translation: "they cannot understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: their hearts cannot perceive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: "the things that I have made" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: the work of my hands

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "hands" represents Yahweh. Alternate translation: "It was I who" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: It was my hands that

contextId.occurrenceNote: The words "knee" and "tongue" represent the people. Alternate translation: "Every person will kneel before me, and everyone will swear" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: To me every knee will bend, every tongue will swear

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Mouth" refers to someone speaking. Alternate translation: "I spoke these things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: they came out from my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" refers to Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I laid the foundation of the earth, and I spread out the heavens" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my hand laid the foundation of the earth, and my right hand spread out the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my ear" refers to Yahweh's servant. Yahweh enabling him to hear and understand what Yahweh teaches him is spoken of as if Yahweh awakened his ear from sleep. Alternate translation: "he has enabled me to understand what he says" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he awakens my ear to hear

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding one's face means to protect oneself. Alternate translation: "I did not defend myself when they mocked me and spat on me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I did not hide my face from acts of shame and spitting

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my face" refers to the servant. The servant being steadfastly determined to obey Yahweh is spoken of as if his face were as hard as flint. Alternate translation: "so I am absolutely determined" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: so I have made my face like flint

contextId.occurrenceNote: People speak as if Yahweh's arm were asleep because it has not been helping them. Here the "arm of Yahweh" represents Yahweh, specifically him helping people. The word "Awake" is repeated to show that they need God's help urgently. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: Awake, awake ... arm of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This uses a person's head to mean the person as a whole. Alternate translation: "they will be glad forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: with gladness forever on their heads

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "bread" represents food in general. This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: "nor will he be without food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: nor will he lack bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is referred to by his hand to emphasize that he is the one who gave the bowl to his people. Alternate translation: "that he gave to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: out of the hand of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses the word "one" here to refer to all of the oppressed people. Alternate translation: "you oppressed people and drunken people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: you oppressed one and drunken one

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "feet" represents a messenger who is walking. Alternate translation: "It is beautiful to see a messenger coming over the mountains to announce good news" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: How beautiful on the mountains are the feet of the messenger who brings good news

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eye" represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "every one of them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: every eye of theirs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "bread" represents food in general. It is implied that the people were buying things to eat that were not really food. Alternate translation: "for things to eat that are not really food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: for what is not bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "mouth" represents Yahweh himself. Alternate translation: "the word that I speak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my word will be that goes from my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "hand" represents the whole person and emphasizes the person's actions or behaviors. Alternate translation: "does not do evil things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: keeps his hand from doing any evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people are represented by their "feet." God did not allow long travels or work on the day of rest. Alternate translation: "you stop traveling and doing what you want to do on the Sabbath, my holy day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: you turn back your feet from traveling on the Sabbath day, and from doing your own pleasure on my holy day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "mouth" symbolizes what Yahweh says. Alternate translation: "for Yahweh has spoken it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: for the mouth of Yahweh has spoken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here people are represented by their "feet." This speaks of them doing something quickly as their feet running to it. Alternate translation: "They are quick to do evil things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Their feet run to evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Take the stones out of the road to make it smooth." Stones represent all the obstacles to quick travel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Gather out the stones

contextId.occurrenceNote: These ancestors of the nation of Israel would not able to identify their descendants because they changed so much. "Abraham" and "Israel" represent the people from the distant past. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: though Abraham does not know us, and Israel does not recognize us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the "eye" refers to the whole person. Alternate translation: "nor has anyone seen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: nor eye seen

contextId.occurrenceNote: "The sword" represents various weapons of war that Yahweh will use to punish those who do not respond to Yahweh's call. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: appoint you for the sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is represented by his hand which emphasizes his power and authority. Alternate translation: "I have made all these things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: My hand has made all these things

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Bones" refers to the whole body. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: your bones will sprout

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Sword" is one weapon that represents all of warfare and killing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: with his sword
